prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors considered by the Panel—Preferences of the parties

para.paratext: The Panel does not appear to give considerable weight to the suggestions or even stipulations of the parties in selection of a particular transferee judge. The agreement of all parties on this question may be considered by the Panel.[1] The Panel has declined to transfer cases to a transferee judge agreed to by all parties.[2] In one case a union involved in the litigation indicated it had no objection to transfer so long as the case were not assigned to a particular judge.[3] The case was assigned by the Panel to that judge. The Panel undoubtedly considers suggestions of the parties in this regard, but the proper role of the parties' view as to a favored transferee judge is limited. The Panel does not give the parties an opportunity to judge-shop, nor does it defer to the parties' wishes in this regard. Arguments directed to preventing a particular judge from being assigned as transferee judge are equally likely to be rejected by the Panel.[4]

The parties may, however, influence the selection of a transferee judge by bringing facts bearing on other factors to the Panel's attention. For example, docket conditions are clearly of interest to the Panel, and the parties may be privy to facts bearing on the selection process not known to the Panel.[5] These facts should be included in an affidavit and filed with the Panel.

Despite the occasional interest of the Panel in counsel's views on selection of a transferee judge, this is ultimately a question the Panel decides for itself. The Panel is quite ready to ignore the positions taken by the parties, especially when the odor of forum shopping is present.

In the Breast Implant Litigation,[6] the Panel expressed its displeasure at the arguments of counsel it found included charges of forum shopping. It rejected the arguments of both sides in a contentious argument over the appropriate transferee court, finding that while either district and judge would be perfectly appropriate, the mere fact of the “acrimonious dispute among counsel” would warrant selection of another judge.[7]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See In re Palizzio, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 241 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
See, e.g., In re Water Meters, 304 F. Supp. 873, 874 (J.P.M.L. 1969).
See In re Southwestern Bell Telephone Co. Maternity Benefits Litigation, 400 F. Supp. 1400, 1401 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

This factor is closely related to the Panel's oft-stated refusal to consider the possibility of adverse rulings by a transferee court judge as a basis for ordering transfer. This factor is discussed in § 5:41.
The role of docket conditions is discussed in § 7:8.
In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation, 793 F. Supp. 1098, 1100 (J.P.M.L. 1992).
